questions.text: A 14-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 10-day history of vaginal bleeding. The flow is heavy with the passage of clots. Since menarche 1 year ago, menses have occurred at irregular 26- to 32-day intervals and last 3 to 6 days. Her last menstrual period was 4 weeks ago. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 106/70 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows vaginal bleeding. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Her hemoglobin is 13.1 g/dL. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral or IV tranexamic acid is a second-line agent used for treating blood loss in acute AUB when other options have failed. Tranexamic acid acts within 2–3 hours of administration and should not be used in women at a high risk of thrombosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Minimally invasive endometrial ablation is the preferred approach in hemodynamically stable women for whom medical therapy for AUB is unsuccessful or contraindicated, but it should only be performed in patients who do not wish to bear any more children. It provides long-term improvement of uterine bleeding symptoms by destroying a thin layer of the endometrium (e.g., with extreme cold, heat, or radiofrequency energy). Hysteroscopy prior to ablation may be useful for identifying and treating intrauterine structural abnormalities (e.g., polyps or fibroids).

C) INCORRECT:

Transcatheter uterine artery embolization is the first-line therapy in women with AUB due to uterine arteriovenous malformation (AVM) that can be identified on color Doppler ultrasound. Uterine AVMs are very rare and can be congenital or acquired. Acquired uterine AVMs should be suspected in women with profuse intermittent bleeding after uterine surgery (e.g., dilation and curettage, cesarean section). This patient has no history of surgical procedures performed on the uterus or profuse bleeding during menses since menarche (in keeping with congenital uterine AVM), making an AVM unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Dilation and uterine curettage with concomitant hysteroscopy is the preferred approach in hemodynamically unstable women with severe AUB after immediate supportive measures (e.g., fluid resuscitation, blood transfusion) have been implemented. It is both diagnostic and therapeutic (i.e., used to identify intrauterine pathologies, take tissue samples, remove excess uterine lining) and preserves fertility as well. If performed rapidly, it may decrease bleeding in less than an hour.
Image Description:

A gynecological procedure in which the cervix is widened using dilators of increasing diameters (left image) in order to allow insertion of a curette into the uterus for therapeutic or diagnostic tissue removal (right image).

E) CORRECT:

Administration of high-dose oral conjugated estrogen is the treatment of choice in hemodynamically stable women with acute AUB, irrespective of the underlying cause. High levels of estrogen trigger rapid growth of the endometrium and thereby stop sudden, heavy bleeding from the uterine surface. Surgical treatment is needed if the patient does not respond to medical treatment or is hemodynamically unstable, bleeding is severe, medical management is contraindicated, or the underlying medical condition requires surgical repair. Conjugated estrogen therapy is contraindicated in women with breast cancer and/or those at a high risk of thrombosis.

F) INCORRECT:

An intrauterine tamponade (e.g., intrauterine balloon or gauze packing) would be the initial step to decrease severe bleeding in a hemodynamically unstable woman with acute AUB. A tamponade, in addition to intravenous fluids and blood transfusions, serves to stabilize the patient until definitive therapy can be administered.
questions.hint: Acute abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) in a girl who attained menarche only one year ago is most likely caused by anovulation due to an immature hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis. Anovulation leads to a deficit in progesterone production, while unopposed estrogen continues to cause abnormal growth of the endometrial lining and vessels. Spontaneous bleeding may result from sloughing of the endometrial lining. If increasing estrogen triggers negative feedback in the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis, a drop in FSH/LH and estrogen levels leads to a sudden loss of endometrium that can cause heavy and prolonged bleeding.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of vaginal bleeding for 2–5 days every 2–3 weeks. The flow is heavy with the passage of clots requiring a thick pad every 2–3 hours. Menarche occurred at 10 years of age, and menses previously occurred at regular 28- to 32-day intervals and lasted for 5 days with normal flow. Her only medication is a multivitamin. She has no children. Her mother was diagnosed with ovarian cancer at 60 years of age. She is 158 cm (5 ft 2 in) tall and weighs 86 kg (190 lb); BMI is 34 kg/m2. Her temperature is 36.6°C (97.8°F), pulse is 86/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows a normal-sized uterus. Laboratory studies, including a complete blood count, thyroid function tests, and coagulation studies are within the reference ranges. A urine pregnancy test is negative. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Endometrial ablation is the surgical removal of the lining of the uterus and is used to treat benign causes of AUB (e.g., fibroids). Fibroids typically manifest with heavy, regular bleeding rather than the irregular bleeding seen here. While endometrial ablation would reduce this patient's bleeding, it would not be appropriate for the diagnosis or treatment of endometrial hyperplasia, which is the likely cause of this patient's symptoms.

B) CORRECT:

Endometrial sampling is indicated in the diagnostic workup of patients < 45 years of age with any of the following: persistent bleeding despite pharmacological treatment, unopposed estrogen (e.g., due to obesity or polycystic ovary syndrome), or other risk factors for endometrial hyperplasia or neoplasia (e.g., type 2 diabetes, nulliparity, early menarche, obesity). Endometrial sampling is also indicated in patients ≥ 45 years of age with any uterine bleeding and postmenopausal patients with an endometrial thickness > 4 mm. This patient is < 45 years of age and has several risk factors for endometrial cancer (nulliparity, early menarche, obesity). Therefore, the most appropriate next step in management is an endometrial biopsy.

A pelvic ultrasound should be considered in patients with AUB to rule out structural abnormalities (e.g., leiomyomas) and evaluate endometrial thickness. However, because endometrial thickness significantly varies during the menstrual cycle in reproductive-age individuals, pelvic ultrasound is not required before performing an endometrial biopsy.

C) INCORRECT:

Ultrasound may be used in the workup of AUB. However, transvaginal rather than abdominal ultrasound is indicated to rule out structural anomalies and evaluate endometrial thickness. Moreover, a more sensitive diagnostic test is often used first-line in premenopausal patients < 45 years of age with persistent bleeding and risk factors for endometrial cancer (e.g., obesity, nulliparity, early menarche), as seen here.

D) INCORRECT:

Combined oral contraceptives (COCPs) are commonly used to treat AUB in premenopausal patients, as COCPs typically reduce dysmenorrhea and make bleeding lighter and more regular. While this patient has AUB, she also has several risk factors for endometrial cancer (e.g., obesity, nulliparity, early menarche), which warrants further investigation, and, therefore, another step should be performed before the initiation of medical management.

E) INCORRECT:

Cyclic progestin therapy can be used to control heavy menstrual bleeding in premenopausal patients with AUB. However, this patient has several risk factors for endometrial cancer (e.g., obesity, nulliparity, early menarche) that warrant further investigation. Therefore, an additional diagnostic step should be completed before initiating management.
questions.hint: Obesity is associated with unopposed estrogen stimulation. This unopposed stimulation is a risk factor for endometrial hyperplasia, which can manifest with abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB). Patients with AUB with a normal initial laboratory workup and a negative pregnancy test should be evaluated based on their bleeding pattern and risk factors for endometrial cancer.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl comes to the physician because of a 2-year history of irregular menstrual bleeding. Menses have occurred at irregular 45- to 60-day intervals since menarche at the age of 13 years. Her last menstrual period was 5 weeks ago and lasted for 7 days with heavy flow and no cramping. She is not sexually active. She is 171 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 58 kg (128 lb); BMI is 20 kg/m2. Her temperature is 36.6°C (97.8°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows a normal-appearing vagina and cervix. Bimanual examination shows a normal-sized uterus and no palpable adnexal masses. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with nonsecreting pituitary adenomas may present with oligomenorrhea. Nonsecreting pituitary macroadenomas can exert a mass effect on the remaining gland or the hypothalamus, resulting in oligomenorrhea due to deficient FSH and LH. However, additional signs, including headache, visual deficits, and symptoms associated with other hormone deficiencies (e.g., hypothyroidism) would also be expected. Patients with functioning (i.e., hormone-producing) adenomas (e.g., prolactinomas) present with galactorrhea, which is absent in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Endometriosis affects up to 10% of women and manifests with a variety of menstrual abnormalities. However, rather than oligomenorrhea, patients more commonly present with dysmenorrhea, premenstrual or postmenstrual bleeding. The most common symptom is chronic pelvic pain that occurs shortly before the menstrual cycle begins. Rectovaginal tenderness and adnexal masses on physical examination would also be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Polycystic ovary syndrome is characterized by hyperandrogenism, oligoovulation or anovulation, and polycystic ovaries. Patients often present with menstrual irregularities (e.g., primary amenorrhea, oligomenorrhea, secondary amenorrhea) during adolescence. Moreover, signs of obesity, metabolic syndrome, and virilization (e.g., excess hair growth, acne) due to hyperandrogenism would be present. This patient's oligomenorrhea likely results from another underlying cause.

D) CORRECT:

Anovulatory cycles are the most common cause of abnormal uterine bleeding in otherwise healthy adolescents and typically occur up to 2 years after menarche due to an immature hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis. Anovulation leads to a deficit in progesterone production, while unopposed estrogen continues to cause abnormal growth of the endometrial lining and vessels. If increasing estrogen levels trigger negative feedback in the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis, a drop in FSH/LH and estrogen levels leads to a sudden loss of endometrium that can cause heavy and prolonged bleeding. Patients should be reassured that this phenomenon is not pathological by nature and that no further workup is required.

If oligomenorrhea is prolonged (> 2 years), further evaluation is warranted to rule out pathological causes.

E) INCORRECT:

Ovarian insufficiency is characterized by less frequent (or even absent) menstrual cycles and hypoestrogenism in women < 40 years of age. However, patients with ovarian insufficiency typically present with perimenopausal, autonomic symptoms (e.g., hot flashes, heat intolerance), and atrophic features (e.g., breast tenderness, vaginal dryness).
questions.hint: Oligomenorrhea in the first 2 years after menarche is a common finding in otherwise healthy teenagers.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because she has not had menstrual bleeding for the past 2 months. Menses had previously occurred at irregular 15–45 day intervals with moderate to heavy flow. Menarche was at the age of 14 years. Eight months ago, she was diagnosed with bipolar disorder and treatment with risperidone was begun. Her parents report that she is very conscious of her weight and appearance. She is 168 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 76 kg (168 lb); BMI is 27 kg/m2. Pelvic examination shows a normal vagina and cervix. Serum hormone studies show:


Prolactin
14 ng/mL


Follicle-stimulating hormone
5 mIU/mL


Luteinizing hormone
5.2 mIU/mL


Progesterone

0.9 ng/mL (follicular N < 3; luteal N > 3–5)


Testosterone
2.7 nmol/L (N < 3.5)


A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Primary ovarian insufficiency can present with the menstrual irregularities and oligomenorrhea seen in this patient. Chromosomal abnormalities (e.g., Turner syndrome) are a common cause of this condition in adolescence. However, FSH levels are typically very high, which is not the case in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

Oligomenorrhea combined with low progesterone levels strongly suggests anovulatory cycles, which are common in adolescent girls during the first few months or year after menarche, and are caused by immaturity of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis. Low levels of progesterone cause the endometrium to remain in the proliferative phase, which often leads to heavy bleeding during menses as well as irregular menses. Patients should be reassured that menstrual cycles will become more regular and predictable after adolescence and no further treatment is required.

Other causes of anovulation include polycystic ovarian syndrome, hyperprolactinemia, premature ovarian failure, hyperthyroidism, obesity, anorexia, and stress.

C) INCORRECT:

Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) is a common cause of menstrual irregularities, including secondary amenorrhea and oligomenorrhea. This patient is overweight, which is commonly seen in patients with PCOS, but she has no signs of hyperandrogenism such as hirsutism and acne. Furthermore, LH and testosterone would be elevated, which is not the case in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Leiomyomas, or fibroids, most commonly occur in women 25–45 years of age and can cause menstrual abnormalities, including hypermenorrhea, menorrhagia, and dysmenorrhea, but progesterone levels would be normal. Large leiomyomas can cause back or pelvic pain and discomfort, as well as urinary tract or bowel symptoms (e.g., urinary frequency/retention, constipation). This patient's symptoms are not consistent with fibroids.

E) INCORRECT:

Risperidone, which is an atypical antipsychotic, can cause hyperprolactinemia. High levels of prolactin suppress the hypothalamic secretion of GnRH, resulting in hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. Irregular menstrual cycles, galactorrhea, and obesity can occur secondary to risperidone intake. FSH and LH levels would be reduced, and serum prolactin levels would be elevated, which is not the case in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Bulimia nervosa can cause hypogonadotropic hypogonadism with secondary amenorrhea. It primarily affects young women, and the BMI in individuals with bulimia is typically normal or elevated (≥ 18.5 kg/m2), which is consistent with this patient's presentation. Although this patient is conscious of her weight, she does not have a history of binge eating or periods of starvation, nor symptoms of purging, such as swollen parotid glands and poor dental status, which would raise suspicion for bulimia nervosa. In addition, FSH and LH would likely be reduced.
questions.hint: Oligomenorrhea, which is preceded by irregular menstrual cycles and menorrhagia, is common in adolescents during the first few months to years after menarche.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, comes to the physician because of an 8-month history of heavy bleeding and severe pelvic cramping during her menstrual period. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals and last for 5–6 days, during which she needs to use 6–8 pads daily. The pelvic cramps usually begin 2 days before the onset of bleeding. Naproxen provides only mild pain relief, and tranexamic acid therapy did not alleviate her symptoms. She worked as a janitor until 2 weeks ago when she was fired for missing several shifts within 1 week because of her symptoms. She does not want to have any more children and underwent tubal ligation 1 year ago. Both of her children were delivered via uncomplicated vaginal deliveries. She is sexually active in a monogamous relationship with her husband. Her only medication is a daily multivitamin. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 68 kg (150 lb); BMI is 25 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination, including pelvic examination, shows no abnormalities. Results of laboratory studies, including a complete blood count, thyroid function tests, and coagulation studies, are within the reference ranges. Transvaginal ultrasonography shows no abnormalities. Endometrial biopsy specimen shows no sign of malignancy. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Combined oral contraceptive pill (COCP) therapy is a first-line treatment for HMB, especially when symptoms persist despite NSAID use. However, COCPs are contraindicated in patients ≥ 35 years of age who smoke ≥ 15 cigarettes/day due to increased risk of cardiovascular complications.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient's HMB and severe cyclical pain significantly reduce her quality of life, so she requires treatment.

C) CORRECT:

Endometrial ablation is a treatment option for patients with ovulatory HMB and no desire for future pregnancy when medical therapy is unsuccessful or contraindicated. In this patient, NSAIDs only provided minimal pain relief, and treatment with tranexamic acid did not improve her symptoms. Moreover, oral contraceptives are contraindicated because of her smoking history and age. Finally, this patient does not have any contraindications for endometrial ablation, such as pregnancy, active pelvic infection, presence of an intrauterine device, and a history of uterine surgery, or complex or atypical endometrial hyperplasia or cancer.

HMB is a form of abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB). The most common causes of AUB can be classified using the PALM-COEIN system: Polyps, Adenomyosis, Leiomyomas, Malignancy and hyperplasia, Coagulopathy, Ovulatory dysfunction, Endometrial, Iatrogenic, Not otherwise classified. This patient presents with HMB in combination with normal findings on physical examination, laboratory evaluation, ultrasonography, and biopsy, which is consistent with endometrial AUB, a diagnosis of exclusion.

D) INCORRECT:

Hysterectomy is a definitive treatment option for patients with HMB who do not desire future pregnancy. However, hysterectomy is an invasive procedure with a high risk of complications, and it is therefore only indicated in patients who do not respond to any other treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

A copper intrauterine device (IUD) is not indicated for the treatment of HMB and may even worsen symptoms. On the other hand, a progestin IUD (i.e., levonorgestrel-releasing) is an effective, reversible, easy-to-use treatment option for patients with HMB, with the added benefit of long-term contraception. A progestin IUD is a viable alternative treatment option for this patient, but a copper IUD is not.
questions.hint: This patient has chronic heavy menstrual bleeding (HMB) that significantly impairs her quality of life. She underwent a tubal ligation because she does not want any more children.

questions.text:
A 61-year-old postmenopausal woman with a history of obesity reports 2 months of irregular vaginal bleeding. Ten years ago, she was diagnosed with breast cancer and treated successfully with surgery, radiation therapy, and tamoxifen. She has no family history of breast or gynecologic cancer. Physical examination, including a pelvic examination, is normal. Her most recent Pap test, performed one year ago, was normal, with negative testing for human papillomavirus.
What is the most appropriate next step in this patient’s evaluation?

choices.text: Operative dilatation and curettage of the endometrium

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A Pap test is most useful for cervical cancer screening and is not used to evaluate endometrial cancer. This patient is up to date on her cervical cancer screening; her next routine screening would not be due for another 4 years. The recent negative result also makes cervical cancer an unlikely cause of her postmenopausal bleeding.

B) INCORRECT:

Radiographic imaging could be considered as an alternative to endometrial biopsy in this case, but the imaging should be done via transvaginal ultrasound rather than CT or MRI of the pelvis. Although an ultrasound would be acceptable, an endometrial biopsy is typically preferred because it is a simple procedure with a high sensitivity and provides tissue diagnosis. If an ultrasound is pursued, then the thickness of the endometrium is used to assess the risk of endometrial cancer. Typically, an endometrial thickness of <4 mm in patients with postmenopausal bleeding reliably excludes endometrial cancer; the negative predictive value approaches 99%. Patients who have an endometrial stripe >4 mm require further evaluation.

C) INCORRECT:

Operative dilatation and curettage is unnecessarily invasive and is not indicated for the initial evaluation of a woman with postmenopausal bleeding.

D) CORRECT:

Irregular vaginal bleeding in a postmenopausal woman should raise concern for endometrial cancer. Risk factors for endometrial cancer include obesity, polycystic ovary syndrome, use of estrogen replacement therapy, use of tamoxifen, older age, and certain familial genetic disorders such as Lynch syndrome. Endometrial cancer is most often diagnosed in the sixth decade of life; complex endometrial hyperplasia can increase the risk.

Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen-receptor modulator. Although its primary therapeutic effect in breast cancer treatment is due to its antiestrogenic properties, this drug also has modest estrogenic activity. In standard doses, it can be associated with endometrial proliferation, hyperplasia, polyp formation, and uterine carcinoma and sarcoma. Screening for endometrial cancer with routine transvaginal ultrasonography, endometrial biopsy, or both has not been shown to be effective in asymptomatic patients using tamoxifen.

Postmenopausal women who experience vaginal bleeding and have a history of tamoxifen use should undergo evaluation with in-office endometrial biopsy.

Key learning point: The most appropriate test to evaluate a postmenopausal woman who was treated with tamoxifen for several years and now presents with irregular vaginal bleeding is an in-office endometrial biopsy.

E) INCORRECT:

Radiographic imaging could be considered as an alternative to endometrial biopsy in this case, but the imaging should be done via transvaginal ultrasound rather than CT or MRI of the pelvis. Although an ultrasound would be acceptable, an endometrial biopsy is typically preferred because it is a simple procedure with a high sensitivity and provides tissue diagnosis. If an ultrasound is pursued, then the thickness of the endometrium is used to assess the risk of endometrial cancer. Typically, an endometrial thickness of <4 mm in patients with postmenopausal bleeding reliably excludes endometrial cancer; the negative predictive value approaches 99%. Patients who have an endometrial stripe >4 mm require further evaluation.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old woman with no significant medical history reports that her menses have been heavier and more painful for the past 3 years. She states that her menses have always lasted for 5 days, but now she is bleeding for 7 days and passing clots the size of oranges for 4 of the 7 days. The cramping pain of her menses has responded well to treatment with ibuprofen. She denies feeling tired or lightheaded.
On examination, her vital signs are normal. Bimanual examination reveals a mildly enlarged uterus without any specific mass lesions.
Which one of the following tests is most appropriate to evaluate this patient?

choices.text: Measurement of estradiol and follicle-stimulating hormone levels

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hysteroscopy is appropriate for women with suspected intrauterine pathology where a biopsy is indicated. Hysteroscopy would not precede a pelvic ultrasound in a 37-year-old woman with abnormal uterine bleeding.

B) INCORRECT:

Endometrial biopsy is not indicated for a premenopausal woman with regular menstrual cycles. Endometrial biopsy is generally used to investigate dysfunctional uterine bleeding in women who are at least 45 years old, women with a history of exposure to unopposed estrogen, and women with an abnormally thickened endometrium on pelvic ultrasound.

C) INCORRECT:

Estradiol and follicle-stimulating hormone levels would help differentiate perimenopause from primary ovarian insufficiency, but measuring these levels is not indicated for the evaluation of abnormal uterine bleeding.

D) CORRECT:

The normal menstrual cycle lasts 21 to 35 days; the normal duration of flow is about 5 days with less than 80 mL of blood lost. Abnormal uterine bleeding is bleeding that is abnormal in flow or cycle. Menorrhagia is cyclical heavy menstrual bleeding. The most common causes of abnormal uterine bleeding include anatomical uterine pathologies, such as endometrial polyps, adenomyosis, uterine leiomyomas, endometrial hyperplasia, and endometrial carcinoma.

The optimal approach to investigating abnormal uterine bleeding has not been established for a woman with a normal-size uterus; however, a woman with an enlarged uterus should undergo imaging. A pelvic ultrasound is optimal because it provides better and more cost-effective imaging than a pelvic MRI.

Key learning point: The most appropriate test to evaluate a premenopausal woman with recent menorrhagia and an enlarged uterus is pelvic ultrasound.

E) INCORRECT:

The optimal approach to investigating abnormal uterine bleeding has not been established for a woman with a normal-size uterus; however, a woman with an enlarged uterus should undergo imaging. A pelvic ultrasound is optimal because it provides better and more cost-effective imaging than a pelvic MRI.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old woman with obesity, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes reports two episodes of vaginal bleeding during the past 6 months. On each occasion, light spotting lasted for approximately 3 days. She experienced natural menopause at age 53.
The remainder of her review of systems is negative. Physical examination is unremarkable. A transvaginal ultrasound shows a 7-mm endometrial stripe.
Which one of the following diagnostic approaches is most appropriate in this case?

choices.text: CT of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A progesterone challenge test is used in the evaluation of amenorrhea in premenopausal women, not for the evaluation of postmenopausal bleeding.

B) INCORRECT:

Observation with repeat ultrasound in 6 months is not adequate in this situation.

C) INCORRECT:

A hysterectomy is sometimes indicated for persistent, bothersome postmenopausal bleeding, but a presurgical endometrial biopsy to evaluate for malignancy should be the first step, even in those cases.

D) INCORRECT:

Transvaginal ultrasound is superior to pelvic CT for uterine imaging. Performing CT in this patient would not add useful information.

E) CORRECT:

Postmenopausal bleeding is always considered abnormal and should prompt evaluation of the endometrium. Possible causes include vaginal or endometrial atrophy, endometrial polyps, cervical malignancy, and endometrial hyperplasia or malignancy. Fewer than 10% of women with postmenopausal bleeding have endometrial malignancy.

When the endometrial lining is 4 mm or less, transvaginal ultrasound has a negative predictive value for endometrial cancer that approaches 99%. Women who have an endometrial stripe >4 mm require further evaluation; this may consist of in-office endometrial biopsy, hysteroscopy with biopsy, or dilation and curettage.

A hysterectomy is sometimes indicated for persistent, bothersome postmenopausal bleeding, but presurgical endometrial sampling to evaluate for malignancy should be the first step, even in those cases.

Key learning point: Postmenopausal bleeding requires further workup in a woman with an ultrasound-measured endometrial stripe of greater than 4 mm.

questions.text:
A 13-year-old girl comes to the pediatrician for a follow-up appointment 10 days after an urgent care visit for heavy menstrual bleeding. She reports that her first menstrual period started 15 days ago. There was no significant pain, but she had to change her pad every 3 hours, and she bled through to her clothes and bedsheets several times. Her mother brought her to the urgent care center on the 5th day of her period, where they drew labs and prescribed her oral iron supplements to take daily, and birth control pills to take every 6 hours until the bleeding stopped. The bleeding stopped the following day, after which she completed a three-day tapering regimen of the birth control pills.
The patient reports that she is quite tired and has a headache. She has no significant medical history. The patient is adopted and family history is unknown. She has never been sexually active.
Vital signs are within normal limits. A complete physical examination is notable only for pallor and mild comedonal acne.
Laboratory results from the urgent care visit are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
6000
4500–11,000


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
9.9
12.0–16.0


Hematocrit (%)
29.7
36.0–46.0


Mean corpuscular volume (μm3)
77
80–100


Mean corpuscular hemoglobin (pg/erythrocyte)
28.0
26.0–34.0


Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (g/dL)
32.0
31.0–37.0


Red-cell distribution width (%)
12.0
11.5–14.5


Platelet count (per mm3)
320,000
150,000–350,000


Neutrophils (%)
65
40–70


Bands (%)
0
0–10


Lymphocytes (%)
25
22–44


Monocytes (%)
8
4–11


Eosinophils (%)
0
0–8


Basophils (%)
2
0–3


Ferritin (ng/mL)
8
10–200


Prothrombin time (sec)
12.0
11.1–13.1


Activated partial-thromboplastin time (sec)
30.0
22.1–35.1


Fibrinogen (mg/dL)
250
150–400


TSH (μU/mL)
1.4
0.5–4.7


Urine hCG
Negative
Negative


Which one of the following tests is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pelvic ultrasonography is not routinely required when evaluating adolescents with heavy menstrual bleeding because structural causes of abnormal uterine bleeding are rare in this age group. It is considered only if the bleeding fails to respond to initial medical treatment or if the bleeding is severe enough to warrant inpatient management.

B) INCORRECT:

Factor V Leiden is an inherited disorder of excessive blood clotting (e.g., deep vein thromboses, pulmonary emboli) rather than bleeding.

C) INCORRECT:

Free and total testosterone levels are measured in the workup of certain endocrine disorders, including polycystic ovary syndrome. In patients with heavy menstrual bleeding, free and total testosterone are not routinely required and are only obtained if there are clinical signs of hyperandrogenism (e.g., significant acne, hirsutism).

D) INCORRECT:

A factor IX assay is performed to diagnose hemophilia B. In a patient with heavy menstrual bleeding, a factor IX assay is not routinely required and is only performed if there is evidence of hemophilia on the initial workup (i.e., prolonged aPTT).

E) CORRECT:

Heavy menstrual bleeding (HMB) can result in anemia and symptoms such as headaches, fatigue, and poor cognition. In adolescents, the most common cause of HMB is anovulation due to the immaturity of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis, but this diagnosis is made by excluding other causes. Bleeding disorders are the second most frequent cause of HMB in adolescents, with von Willebrand disease (vWD) being the most common inherited bleeding disorder associated with HMB. Additional causes of HMB include thyroid disease, hyperprolactinemia, polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), and obesity. Structural causes of HMB are rare in adolescents.

For adolescents presenting with HMB, the initial laboratory evaluation should consist of urine hCG, CBC, TSH, ferritin, and a coagulation panel. In addition to PT, aPTT, INR, and fibrinogen, the initial coagulation panel should include tests for vWD such as vWF antigen, ristocetin cofactor activity, and factor VIII activity. However, testing for vWD should not take place within one week of exposure to exogenous estrogen, as this can result in false negative results. Further tests for bleeding disorders should be based on the results of this initial workup. Sexually active adolescents should also be screened for STIs. Other hormone studies (e.g., testosterone, DHEAS, prolactin) are typically unnecessary in the initial workup unless the patient has signs of PCOS or hyperprolactinemia. Pelvic ultrasound is also not necessary as part of the initial assessment unless the patient is experiencing features of severe HMB such as hemodynamic instability, severe anemia (hemoglobin < 8 g/dL), or having to use >1 pad per hour for more than 2 hours.

A patient who presents with features of severe HMB would require admission and, if indicated, a blood transfusion. Hemodynamically stable inpatients may be managed with antifibrinolytics, IV estrogen, or combined oral contraceptive pills (COCs) that contain at least 30 mcg of ethinyl estradiol. If COCs are used, they should be taken every 6–8 hours until bleeding stops and then tapered. Bleeding usually stops within 1–2 days of COC administration. Outpatient maintenance therapy options include progestin-only or COCs (often used continuously) plus oral iron. Patients with bleeding disorders may require additional therapy specific to their disease.

Key learning point: The initial laboratory evaluation for patients presenting with heavy menstrual bleeding at menarche should include testing for von Willebrand disease.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl comes to the office because of a 2-year history of irregular menstrual bleeding. Menses have occurred at irregular 45- to 60-day intervals since menarche at the age of 13 years. Her last menstrual period was 5 weeks ago and lasted for 7 days with heavy flow and no cramping. She is 171 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 58 kg (128 lb); BMI is 20 kg/m2. Her temperature is 36.6°C (97.8°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows a normal-appearing vagina and cervix. Bimanual examination shows a normal-sized uterus and no palpable adnexal masses. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with nonsecreting pituitary adenomas may present with oligomenorrhea. Nonsecreting pituitary macroadenomas can exert a mass effect on the remaining gland or the hypothalamus, resulting in oligomenorrhea due to deficient FSH and LH. However, additional signs, including headache, visual deficits, and symptoms associated with other hormone deficiencies (e.g., hypothyroidism) would also be expected. Patients with functioning (i.e., hormone-producing) adenomas (e.g., prolactinomas) present with galactorrhea, which is absent in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Endometriosis affects up to 10% of women and manifests with a variety of menstrual abnormalities. However, rather than oligomenorrhea, patients more commonly present with dysmenorrhea, premenstrual or postmenstrual bleeding. The most common symptom is chronic pelvic pain that occurs shortly before the menstrual cycle begins. Rectovaginal tenderness and adnexal masses on physical examination would also be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Polycystic ovary syndrome is characterized by hyperandrogenism, oligoovulation or anovulation, and polycystic ovaries. Patients often present with menstrual irregularities (e.g., primary amenorrhea, oligomenorrhea, secondary amenorrhea) during adolescence. Moreover, signs of obesity, metabolic syndrome, and virilization (e.g., excess hair growth, acne) due to hyperandrogenism would be present. This patient's oligomenorrhea likely results from another underlying cause.

D) CORRECT:

Anovulatory cycles are the most common cause of abnormal uterine bleeding in otherwise healthy adolescents and typically occur up to 2 years after menarche due to an immature hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis. Anovulation leads to a deficit in progesterone production, while unopposed estrogen continues to cause abnormal growth of the endometrial lining and vessels. If increasing estrogen levels trigger negative feedback in the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis, a drop in FSH/LH and estrogen levels leads to a sudden loss of endometrium that can cause heavy and prolonged bleeding. Patients should be reassured that this phenomenon is not pathological by nature and that no further workup is required.

If oligomenorrhea is prolonged (> 2 years), further evaluation is warranted to rule out pathological causes.

E) INCORRECT:

Ovarian insufficiency is characterized by less frequent (or even absent) menstrual cycles and hypoestrogenism in women < 40 years of age. However, patients with ovarian insufficiency typically present with perimenopausal, autonomic symptoms (e.g., hot flashes, heat intolerance), and atrophic features (e.g., breast tenderness, vaginal dryness).
questions.hint: Oligomenorrhea in the first 2 years after menarche is a common finding in otherwise healthy teenagers.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman with no significant medical history reports that her menses have been heavier and more painful for the past 3 years. She states that her menses have always lasted for 5 days, but now she is bleeding for 7 days and passing clots the size of oranges for 4 of the 7 days. The cramping pain of her menses has responded well to treatment with ibuprofen. She denies feeling tired or lightheaded. On examination, her vital signs are normal. Bimanual examination reveals a mildly enlarged uterus without any specific mass lesions. Which one of the following tests is most appropriate to evaluate this patient?

choices.text: Measurement of estradiol and follicle-stimulating hormone levels

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hysteroscopy is appropriate for women with suspected intrauterine pathology where a biopsy is indicated. Hysteroscopy would not be performed before imaging in a 37-year-old woman with abnormal uterine bleeding.

B) INCORRECT:

Endometrial biopsy is not indicated for a premenopausal woman with regular menstrual cycles. Endometrial biopsy is generally used to investigate dysfunctional uterine bleeding in women who are at least 45 years old, women with a history of exposure to unopposed estrogen, and women with an abnormally thickened endometrium on pelvic ultrasound.

C) INCORRECT:

Estradiol and follicle-stimulating hormone levels would help differentiate perimenopause from primary ovarian insufficiency, but measuring these levels is not indicated for the evaluation of abnormal uterine bleeding.

D) CORRECT:

The normal menstrual cycle lasts 21 to 35 days; the normal duration of flow is about 5 days with less than 80 mL of blood lost. Abnormal uterine bleeding is bleeding that is abnormal in flow or cycle. The most common causes of abnormal uterine bleeding include anatomical uterine pathologies, such as endometrial polyps, adenomyosis, uterine leiomyomas, endometrial hyperplasia, and endometrial carcinoma.

The optimal approach to investigating abnormal uterine bleeding has not been established for a woman with a normal-size uterus; however, a woman with an enlarged uterus should undergo imaging. A pelvic ultrasound is optimal because it provides better and more cost-effective imaging than a pelvic MRI.

Key learning point: The most appropriate test to evaluate a premenopausal woman with recent menorrhagia and an enlarged uterus is pelvic ultrasound.

E) INCORRECT:

The optimal approach to investigating abnormal uterine bleeding in a woman with a normal-sized uterus has not been clearly established. However, in cases of an enlarged uterus, imaging is recommended. A different imaging modality is preferred over MRI due to its superior and more cost-effective results.
questions.hint: Passing of blood clots larger than 2–3 cm is a clinical indicator for heavy menstrual bleeding.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presents with a 10-day history of vaginal bleeding. The flow is heavy with the passage of clots. Since menarche 1 year ago, menses have occurred at irregular 26- to 32-day intervals and last 3 to 6 days. Her last menstrual period was 4 weeks ago. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 106/70 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows vaginal bleeding. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Her hemoglobin is 13.1 g/dL. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral or IV tranexamic acid is a second-line agent used for treating blood loss in acute AUB when other options have failed. Tranexamic acid acts within 2–3 hours of administration and should not be used in women at a high risk of thrombosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Minimally invasive endometrial ablation is the preferred approach in hemodynamically stable women for whom medical therapy for AUB is unsuccessful or contraindicated, but it should only be performed in patients who do not wish to bear any more children. It provides long-term improvement of uterine bleeding symptoms by destroying a thin layer of the endometrium (e.g., with extreme cold, heat, or radiofrequency energy). Hysteroscopy prior to ablation may be useful for identifying and treating intrauterine structural abnormalities (e.g., polyps or fibroids).

C) INCORRECT:

Dilation and uterine curettage with concomitant hysteroscopy is the preferred approach in hemodynamically unstable women with severe AUB after immediate supportive measures (e.g., fluid resuscitation, blood transfusion) have been implemented. It is both diagnostic and therapeutic (i.e., used to identify intrauterine pathologies, take tissue samples, remove excess uterine lining) and preserves fertility as well. If performed rapidly, it may decrease bleeding in less than an hour.
Image Description:

A gynecological procedure in which the cervix is widened using dilators of increasing diameters (left image) in order to allow insertion of a curette into the uterus for therapeutic or diagnostic tissue removal (right image).

D) CORRECT:

Administration of high-dose oral conjugated estrogen is the treatment of choice in hemodynamically stable women with acute AUB, irrespective of the underlying cause. High levels of estrogen trigger rapid growth of the endometrium and thereby stop sudden, heavy bleeding from the uterine surface. Surgical treatment is needed if the patient does not respond to medical treatment or is hemodynamically unstable, bleeding is severe, medical management is contraindicated, or the underlying medical condition requires surgical repair. Conjugated estrogen therapy is contraindicated in women with breast cancer and/or those at a high risk of thrombosis.

E) INCORRECT:

An intrauterine tamponade (e.g., intrauterine balloon or gauze packing) would be the initial step to decrease severe bleeding in a hemodynamically unstable woman with acute AUB. A tamponade, in addition to intravenous fluids and blood transfusions, serves to stabilize the patient until definitive therapy can be administered.
questions.hint: Acute abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) in a girl who attained menarche only one year ago is most likely caused by anovulation due to an immature hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old woman presents with a six-month history of frequent, prolonged menstrual bleeding. She reports changing her pad hourly during heavier days but denies passing large clots. She has no significant medical or family history, does not smoke, and has a normal BMI. She declines any current sexual activity and expresses frustration with the unpredictability of her cycles. Physical examination, complete blood count, and pelvic ultrasound are normal.
What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

High-dose intravenous estrogen is used for acute, severe uterine bleeding requiring rapid hemostasis. This patient has chronic heavy menstrual bleeding but is hemodynamically stable with normal blood counts. Her condition does not warrant aggressive intervention like intravenous estrogen.

B) INCORRECT:

Endometrial biopsy is used to assess endometrial pathology, especially in older patients or those with risk factors like obesity or diabetes. In this 18-year-old with normal ultrasound and no risk factors, the likelihood of significant findings is low. Her presentation suggests functional bleeding due to anovulatory cycles, making biopsy unnecessary.

C) INCORRECT:

The levonorgestrel intrauterine device reduces menstrual bleeding by thinning the endometrial lining. However, in an 18-year-old nulliparous patient not sexually active, the invasiveness and potential discomfort of insertion make it less appropriate as an initial step. Oral hormonal therapies are preferred for adolescents.

D) CORRECT:

Abnormal uterine bleeding in adolescents often results from anovulatory cycles due to an immature hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis. This patient, with normal pelvic ultrasound and complete blood count, likely has dysfunctional uterine bleeding. Combined oral contraceptives, containing estrogen and progestin, stabilize the endometrial lining, control excessive bleeding, and promote regular menstrual cycles. This approach addresses the underlying anovulatory bleeding and aligns with management strategies for young women with similar presentations.

Key learning point: Oral contraceptive pills are a first-line treatment for abnormal uterine bleeding in young women without risk factors for endometrial pathology, as they help regulate the menstrual cycle and reduce menstrual flow.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old obese woman presents with two months of frequent, heavy, and prolonged uterine bleeding. She reports intermittent bleeding between periods and an increase in bleeding over the last several cycles. Her last Pap smear, performed nine months ago, was normal. She has no significant past gynecologic history. BMI is 38. Pelvic examination shows no visible cervical lesions.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A Pap smear screens for cervical abnormalities, not endometrial pathology. This patient’s obesity and bleeding pattern suggest a uterine source, warranting endometrial evaluation. Her recent normal Pap smear and lack of cervical lesions further support focusing on the endometrium.

B) CORRECT:

In a 48-year-old obese woman with abnormal uterine bleeding, endometrial biopsy is crucial to evaluate for endometrial hyperplasia or carcinoma. Obesity increases peripheral conversion of androgens to estrogen, stimulating the endometrium and raising the risk of hyperplasia. Endometrial biopsy provides histopathological evaluation of the uterine lining, essential for detecting malignant or pre-malignant changes. A normal Pap smear does not assess endometrial tissue, making biopsy the most appropriate diagnostic step given her risk factors and clinical presentation.

Key learning point: In cases of persistent abnormal uterine bleeding, especially in women with risk factors such as obesity, an endometrial biopsy is the most appropriate next step to assess for endometrial hyperplasia or cancer.

C) INCORRECT:

Thyroid dysfunction can cause menstrual irregularities, but this patient lacks specific signs of thyroid disease. Her bleeding pattern and obesity suggest unopposed estrogen exposure and potential endometrial pathology, making endometrial evaluation more relevant than thyroid assessment.

D) INCORRECT:

High-dose intravenous estrogen is used for acute management of uncontrolled uterine bleeding, not for chronic abnormal bleeding. This patient’s bleeding pattern suggests a chronic issue, not an acute crisis. Additionally, this treatment does not provide diagnostic information about potential endometrial pathology, which is a concern in an obese, perimenopausal woman.

questions.text:
A 43-year-old woman presents with progressively heavier menstrual bleeding for the past year, with prolonged flow lasting eight days and occasional spotting between cycles. She has no significant family history. Her BMI is 24 kg/m2. Laboratory tests are unremarkable. A recent transvaginal ultrasound reveals a 13-mm endometrial thickness with an echogenic structure projecting into the uterine cavity (see report).
Transvaginal ultrasound: 13-mm endometrial thickness with an echogenic structure projecting into the uterine cavity
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to further evaluate this lesion?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

MRI of the pelvis offers excellent soft tissue resolution and is useful for evaluating complex pelvic anatomy, such as in endometriosis or gynecologic malignancies. However, it is not the best choice for assessing discrete endometrial lesions like polyps, as it does not allow for direct visualization or tissue sampling, which are crucial for histopathological confirmation in cases of abnormal uterine bleeding.

B) INCORRECT:

Hysterosalpingography (HSG) assesses uterine cavity shape and tubal patency, mainly in infertility workups. It provides a two-dimensional outline but lacks resolution for detailed evaluation of intracavitary lesions like polyps or fibroids. HSG does not allow for direct visualization or tissue sampling, making it less suitable for assessing abnormal uterine bleeding in this context.

C) INCORRECT:

Immediate hysteroscopic polypectomy may seem appropriate for an echogenic structure in the uterine cavity, but histopathologic confirmation is essential before therapeutic interventions. In a 43-year-old with abnormal uterine bleeding, ruling out atypical hyperplasia or malignancy is crucial. Hysteroscopy is useful for visualization and sampling, but immediate resection without diagnosis risks mismanagement.

D) CORRECT:

Saline infusion sonohysterography (SIS) enhances visualization of the endometrial cavity by infusing sterile saline, delineating intracavitary structures that may be obscured on routine transvaginal ultrasound. In this patient with abnormal uterine bleeding and an echogenic structure in the uterine cavity, SIS is highly effective for evaluating focal endometrial lesions, such as polyps. It provides detailed information on the lesion’s size, location, and morphology, aiding in management decisions. The saline distension offers enhanced contrast, distinguishing focal lesions from diffuse endometrial thickening.

Key learning point: In cases of abnormal uterine bleeding with an intrauterine lesion, a sonohysterogram is a useful next step to evaluate the uterine cavity and characterize the lesion.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman presents with episodes of light bleeding between her regular menstrual cycles for the past three months to the Outpatient Clinic. She denies any significant pain or recent changes in medication. She has two healthy children and does not desire future fertility. Physical examination, including speculum and bimanual evaluation, is normal. Laboratory tests show hemoglobin 125 g/L (reference range 115–155 g/L) and a negative pregnancy test (see report).
Transvaginal ultrasound: Well-defined 1.5 cm echogenic lesion in the endometrial cavity consistent with an endometrial polyp
What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Dilation and curettage under general anesthesia
Hysteroscopic excision of the intracavitary lesion
Repeat transvaginal ultrasound in three months

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dilation and curettage (D&C) is a blind procedure that lacks direct visualization, risking incomplete removal of a polyp. Hysteroscopy, which allows targeted resection, provides diagnostic confirmation and therapeutic resolution with less invasiveness. D&C is more appropriate for diffuse endometrial pathology, not a well-defined polyp.

B) INCORRECT:

In-office endometrial sampling is used for diffuse endometrial pathology, such as hyperplasia or carcinoma, especially in postmenopausal patients. However, it may miss a discrete lesion like an endometrial polyp, as it is a blind technique not designed for focal pathology. Direct visualization and targeted removal are necessary for comprehensive evaluation.

C) CORRECT:

Hysteroscopic excision is the definitive management for an endometrial polyp, especially with abnormal uterine bleeding. Hysteroscopy allows direct visualization and complete resection of the polyp, ensuring thorough inspection of the endometrial cavity. This approach enables histological examination to rule out atypical hyperplasia or malignancy. Given the patient's multiparity and lack of desire for future fertility, hysteroscopy is favored over less direct procedures, aligning with guidelines prioritizing symptom resolution and accurate diagnosis in women with endometrial polyps and intermenstrual bleeding.

Key learning point: In cases of intermenstrual bleeding with ultrasound findings suggestive of an endometrial polyp, hysteroscopy is the preferred management for both diagnosis and removal of the polyp.

D) INCORRECT:

Repeating the ultrasound assumes the polyp is incidental and can be observed. However, the patient has abnormal uterine bleeding, and the ultrasound confirmed a 1.5 cm endometrial polyp. Delaying intervention may prolong symptoms and delay identification of premalignant changes. Observation is more suitable for asymptomatic individuals.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman presents with intermittent vaginal bleeding over the past two weeks. Her last menstrual period was five weeks ago. She has been using condoms inconsistently for the last few months. On physical examination, there is mild tenderness on bimanual pelvic exam, and no adnexal masses are palpated.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

High-dose estrogen therapy stabilizes the endometrium in anovulatory cycles but is not a diagnostic tool. In this scenario, the possibility of pregnancy-related etiologies necessitates confirming pregnancy status first. Administering estrogen without excluding early gestation could complicate the clinical picture and delay appropriate evaluations.

B) INCORRECT:

Transvaginal ultrasound can visualize gestational structures but requires confirmation of pregnancy first. Without knowing the serum beta-hCG level, interpreting ultrasound findings is challenging, as visualization depends on beta-hCG reaching a discriminatory threshold. Early gestational structures may be too small to assess accurately, leading to misinterpretation.

C) CORRECT:

In a reproductive-age woman with abnormal vaginal bleeding and inconsistent contraceptive use, confirming pregnancy is crucial. The serum beta-hCG test is highly sensitive and provides quantitative data to detect early pregnancy. This is essential for evaluating potential complications like ectopic pregnancy or early intrauterine gestation. A positive result guides further imaging, while a negative result redirects the investigation to other causes. This step is fundamental in guiding management and diagnostic decisions in intermenstrual bleeding.

Key learning point: In women of reproductive age presenting with abnormal uterine bleeding, a beta hCG test is the most appropriate initial investigation to rule out pregnancy.

D) INCORRECT:

Endometrial biopsy evaluates abnormal uterine bleeding when endometrial hyperplasia or carcinoma is suspected, especially in older patients. In a young woman with potential early pregnancy, invasive procedures like biopsy are premature. Intermittent bleeding with a recent last menstrual period suggests early gestational issues, best evaluated with a serum pregnancy test.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman presents with intermittent, painless vaginal bleeding for the last 2 months to the clinic. She is postmenopausal for 10 years, nulliparous, and has a ten-year history of type 2 diabetes. She has a BMI of 35 and a strong family history of colorectal cancer. She denies weight loss or abdominal pain. Vital signs are stable. Pelvic examination reveals no visible cervical lesions (see lab results and report).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Hemoglobin
118 g/L
120 - 160 g/L


Glucose, fasting
8.5 mmol/L
3.5 - 6.5 mmol/L



Transvaginal ultrasound: Endometrial thickness of 9 mm without focal abnormalities
What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In a postmenopausal woman with vaginal bleeding, an endometrial thickness of 9 mm is concerning. Her risk factors increase the likelihood of endometrial pathology. Relying on a repeat ultrasound may delay diagnosis of hyperplasia or carcinoma. Immediate histologic evaluation is warranted.

B) INCORRECT:

High-dose oral progestin therapy is used for endometrial hyperplasia without atypia or in younger women desiring fertility preservation. In this postmenopausal woman with risk factors for endometrial carcinoma, initiating progestin therapy without a confirmed diagnosis may delay identifying malignancy. Endometrial sampling is necessary before considering hormonal therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Pelvic MRI is used for staging endometrial carcinoma, assessing myometrial invasion or cervical extension, not for initial diagnosis. In this patient, the primary concern is evaluating postmenopausal bleeding with a thickened endometrium, which requires histopathologic confirmation via endometrial tissue sampling.

D) CORRECT:

In postmenopausal women with vaginal bleeding, endometrial assessment is crucial due to the risk of endometrial hyperplasia and carcinoma. Risk factors such as obesity, type 2 diabetes, and nulliparity increase the likelihood of unopposed estrogen exposure, leading to endometrial proliferation. An endometrial thickness of 9 mm on transvaginal ultrasound in a postmenopausal patient exceeds the threshold for concern, necessitating histologic evaluation. An office endometrial biopsy is a minimally invasive procedure that allows for histologic examination of the endometrial tissue. This procedure is safe, feasible in an outpatient setting, and provides crucial information on cellular architecture and atypia, distinguishing between benign and malignant conditions. The biopsy results guide subsequent management by assessing glandular proliferation and cellular changes.

Key learning point: In postmenopausal women with abnormal uterine bleeding and increased endometrial thickness, an endometrial biopsy is the appropriate next step to evaluate for hyperplasia or malignancy.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman presents to the clinic with 8 months of progressively heavier menstrual bleeding, passing large clots on her heaviest days. Over-the-counter NSAIDs provide little relief. She smokes a pack daily and has a history of migraines with aura. Physical examination is normal (see lab results and reports).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Hemoglobin
102 g/L
120 - 160 g/L


Platelet count
320 x 109/L
150 - 400 x 109/L


Bleeding time
2 min
up to 4 min


Prothrombin time
11 sec
10 - 13 sec


APTT
37 sec
30 - 40 sec




Pelvic ultrasound: No structural abnormalities
Ristocetin cofactor assay: Platelet agglutination occurs

Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacologic treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intranasal desmopressin is indicated for bleeding due to von Willebrand disease, which manifests with a prolonged bleeding time and a failure of platelet agglutination in a ristocetin cofactor assay. Desmopressin does not address the uterine fibrinolytic pathway involved in menorrhagia.

B) INCORRECT:

High-dose intravenous estrogen is used for acute severe uterine bleeding, not chronic menorrhagia. It poses risks of thromboembolic events in patients with migraines with aura and smokers.

C) INCORRECT:

Combined oral contraceptives reduce menstrual bleeding but contain estrogen, which is contraindicated in patients with migraines with aura due to increased thromboembolic risk, especially in smokers.

D) CORRECT:

Tranexamic acid is an antifibrinolytic agent that reduces menstrual bleeding by inhibiting plasminogen activation, thereby stabilizing fibrin clots in the endometrium. It is effective for menorrhagia and does not have hormonal effects, making it suitable for patients with contraindications to estrogen, such as those with migraines with aura and smokers.

Key learning point: Tranexamic acid is an antifibrinolytic agent used to treat heavy menstrual bleeding by reducing the breakdown of blood clots.

questions.text:
A 49-year-old woman presents with progressively heavier and irregular menstrual bleeding for the past six months. She reports frequent passage of clots and often soaks through an overnight pad every two hours. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus. Her BMI is 35. Pelvic examination reveals a normal-sized uterus without visible cervical lesions. Vital signs are stable.

Blood pressure
140/85 mm Hg

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluating her bleeding?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Diagnostic dilation and curettage (D&C) allows for endometrial sampling but is more invasive than an endometrial biopsy. It is typically reserved for cases where office-based biopsy is insufficient or when endometrial pathology is highly suspected. The patient's stable vital signs and normal-sized uterus suggest that a less invasive method is appropriate for initial evaluation.

B) INCORRECT:

Pap smear is a screening tool for cervical neoplasia, not for evaluating abnormal uterine bleeding. The patient's symptoms and risk factors suggest an endometrial source, not a cervical one. The pelvic examination did not reveal cervical abnormalities, making Pap smear inappropriate for this evaluation.

C) CORRECT:

Endometrial biopsy is the preferred initial diagnostic test for women over 45 with abnormal uterine bleeding, especially with risk factors like obesity and type 2 diabetes mellitus. It allows for histopathologic evaluation of endometrial tissue to detect hyperplasia or carcinoma. This minimally invasive, office-based procedure provides diagnostic clarity regarding potential hormonal or neoplastic processes underlying the symptoms.

Key learning point: In women over 45 with abnormal uterine bleeding, an endometrial biopsy is crucial to rule out endometrial hyperplasia or cancer, especially in the presence of risk factors like obesity and diabetes.

D) INCORRECT:

High-dose estrogen therapy is used for acute heavy menstrual bleeding but is contraindicated here due to the patient's risk factors for endometrial hyperplasia and carcinoma. Administering estrogen without a diagnosis may worsen endometrial proliferation. Histologic evaluation should precede hormone-based treatments.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman with no significant medical history comes to your clinic because her menses have become heavier and more painful over the past 3 years. She reports that her periods previously lasted 5 days, but now she bleeds for 7 days and passes clots the size of oranges for 4 of those days. Her menstrual cramping responds well to ibuprofen. She does not feel tired or lightheaded. Vital signs are normal. On bimanual examination, you find a mildly enlarged uterus without distinct mass lesions. Which one of the following tests is most appropriate to evaluate her condition?

choices.text: Measurement of estradiol and follicle-stimulating hormone levels.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Estradiol and follicle-stimulating hormone levels would help differentiate perimenopause from primary ovarian insufficiency, but measuring these levels is not indicated for the evaluation of abnormal uterine bleeding.

B) CORRECT:

The normal menstrual cycle lasts 21 to 35 days; the normal duration of flow is about 5 days with less than 80 mL of blood lost. Abnormal uterine bleeding is bleeding that is abnormal in flow or cycle. The most common causes of abnormal uterine bleeding include anatomical uterine pathologies, such as endometrial polyps, adenomyosis, uterine leiomyomas, endometrial hyperplasia, and endometrial carcinoma.

The optimal approach to investigating abnormal uterine bleeding has not been established for a woman with a normal-size uterus; however, a woman with an enlarged uterus should undergo imaging. A pelvic ultrasound is optimal because it provides better and more cost-effective imaging than a pelvic MRI.

Key learning point: The most appropriate test to evaluate a premenopausal woman with recent menorrhagia and an enlarged uterus is pelvic ultrasound.

C) INCORRECT:

Hysteroscopy is appropriate for women with suspected intrauterine pathology where a biopsy is indicated. Hysteroscopy would not be performed before imaging in a 37-year-old woman with abnormal uterine bleeding.

D) INCORRECT:

The optimal approach to investigating abnormal uterine bleeding in a woman with a normal-sized uterus has not been clearly established. However, in cases of an enlarged uterus, imaging is recommended. A different imaging modality is preferred over MRI due to its superior and more cost-effective results.

E) INCORRECT:

Endometrial biopsy is not indicated for a premenopausal woman with regular menstrual cycles. Endometrial biopsy is generally used to investigate dysfunctional uterine bleeding in women who are at least 45 years old, women with a history of exposure to unopposed estrogen, and women with an abnormally thickened endometrium on pelvic ultrasound.
questions.hint: Passing of blood clots larger than 2–3 cm is a clinical indicator for heavy menstrual bleeding.

questions.text:
A 39-year-old woman presents to the office with a 6-month history of vaginal bleeding for 2–5 days every 2–3 weeks. The flow is heavy with the passage of clots requiring a thick pad every 2–3 hours. Menarche occurred at 10 years of age, and menses previously occurred at regular 28- to 32-day intervals and lasted for 5 days with normal flow. Her only medication is a multivitamin. She has no children. Her mother was diagnosed with ovarian cancer at 60 years of age. The patient is 158 cm (5 ft 2 in) tall and weighs 86 kg (190 lb); BMI is 34 kg/m2. Vital signs reveal:


Temperature
36.6°C (97.8°F)


Blood pressure
110/70 mmHg


Heart rate
86/min


Pelvic examination reveals a normal-sized uterus. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies, including a complete blood count, thyroid function tests, and coagulation studies are within the reference ranges. A urine pregnancy test is negative. The most appropriate next step in management is
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Endometrial ablation is the surgical removal of the lining of the uterus and is used to treat benign causes of AUB (e.g., fibroids). Fibroids typically manifest with heavy, regular bleeding rather than the irregular bleeding seen here. While endometrial ablation would reduce this patient's bleeding, it would not be appropriate for the diagnosis or treatment of endometrial hyperplasia, which is the likely cause of this patient's symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Ultrasound may be used in the workup of AUB. However, transvaginal rather than abdominal ultrasound is indicated to rule out structural anomalies and evaluate endometrial thickness. Moreover, a more sensitive diagnostic test is often used first-line in premenopausal patients < 45 years of age with persistent bleeding and risk factors for endometrial cancer (e.g., obesity, nulliparity, early menarche), as seen here.

C) CORRECT:

Endometrial sampling is indicated in the diagnostic workup of patients < 45 years of age with any of the following: persistent bleeding despite pharmacological treatment, unopposed estrogen (e.g., due to obesity or polycystic ovary syndrome), or other risk factors for endometrial hyperplasia or neoplasia (e.g., type 2 diabetes, nulliparity, early menarche, obesity). Endometrial sampling is also indicated in patients ≥ 45 years of age with any uterine bleeding and postmenopausal patients with an endometrial thickness > 4 mm. This patient is < 45 years of age and has several risk factors for endometrial cancer (nulliparity, early menarche, obesity). Therefore, the most appropriate next step in management is an endometrial biopsy.

A pelvic ultrasound should be considered in patients with AUB to rule out structural abnormalities (e.g., leiomyomas) and evaluate endometrial thickness. However, because endometrial thickness significantly varies during the menstrual cycle in reproductive-age individuals, pelvic ultrasound is not required before performing an endometrial biopsy.

D) INCORRECT:

Cyclic progestin therapy can be used to control heavy menstrual bleeding in premenopausal patients with AUB. However, this patient has several risk factors for endometrial cancer (e.g., obesity, nulliparity, early menarche) that warrant further investigation. Therefore, an additional diagnostic step should be completed before initiating management.

E) INCORRECT:

Combined oral contraceptives (COCPs) are commonly used to treat AUB in premenopausal patients, as COCPs typically reduce dysmenorrhea and make bleeding lighter and more regular. While this patient has AUB, she also has several risk factors for endometrial cancer (e.g., obesity, nulliparity, early menarche), which warrants further investigation, and, therefore, another step should be performed before the initiation of medical management.
questions.hint: Obesity is associated with unopposed estrogen stimulation. This unopposed stimulation is a risk factor for endometrial hyperplasia, which can manifest with abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB). Patients with AUB with a normal initial laboratory workup and a negative pregnancy test should be evaluated based on their bleeding pattern and risk factors for endometrial cancer.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with heavy vaginal bleeding that started 8 hours ago. She has soaked through 6 pads in the past 4 hours and reports feeling weak and dizzy. Her last menstrual period was 4 weeks ago. Vital signs are BP, 90/58; P, 110; T, 37.0°C (98.4°F). Her hemoglobin is 8.2 g/dL. βhCG in urine is negative. After initiating IV access and fluid resuscitation, what is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient shows signs of hemodynamic instability with hypotension, tachycardia, anemia, and clinical signs of volume depletion. After initial fluid resuscitation, high-dose IV conjugated equine estrogen is the appropriate hormonal therapy for hemodynamically unstable patients with acute abnormal uterine bleeding.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral combined contraceptive therapy is appropriate for stable patients with acute abnormal uterine bleeding but would be insufficient for this hemodynamically unstable patient. IV hormonal therapy is required for hemostatic control when patients show signs of hemodynamic compromise.

C) INCORRECT:

While tranexamic acid is used as adjunctive nonhormonal therapy for acute abnormal uterine bleeding, hemodynamically unstable patients with abnormal uterine bleeding require hormonal therapy for rapid hemostatic control. Tranexamic acid as monotherapy lacks the endometrial growth response needed for rapid bleeding cessation in unstable patients.

D) INCORRECT:

Immediate dilation and curettage would be premature as the next step in this hemodynamically unstable patient. While surgical interventions are indicated for severe bleeding and hemodynamic instability, they are reserved for cases with lack of response or contraindications to pharmacotherapy.

E) INCORRECT:

Uterine artery embolization is a minimally invasive interventional procedure reserved for specific causes of abnormal uterine bleeding such as fibroids or arteriovenous malformations, but it is not appropriate as an immediate intervention for hemodynamically unstable patients who require urgent pharmacological hemostatic control.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department with vaginal bleeding over the past 24 hours. She reports saturating a menstrual pad every 30 minutes and feeling lightheaded. Pelvic examination reveals a large amount of bright red blood in the vaginal canal, but the uterus is nontender and of normal size (see lab results).


Heart rate
110/min


Blood pressure
95/66 mm Hg


Respiratory rate
20/min




Test
Result
Normal Values



Hemoglobin
95 g/L
120 - 160 g/L


Human chorionic gonadotropin
1 mIU/mL
< 5 mIU/mL



Two large-bore intravenous lines are placed and fluid resuscitation is initiated. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

High-dose intravenous conjugated estrogens rapidly stabilize the endometrial lining and promote clot formation, providing quick hemostasis. This is crucial for patients with severe vaginal bleeding and signs of hemodynamic instability, such as tachycardia and hypotension. Intravenous administration ensures rapid bioavailability, enhancing vascular constriction and coagulation within the endometrium, making it the optimal choice after initial fluid resuscitation.

Key learning point: In cases of acute heavy uterine bleeding, conjugated estrogen is often used as a first-line treatment to rapidly stabilize the endometrium and reduce bleeding.

B) INCORRECT:

Medroxyprogesterone is used for long-term endometrial stabilization, not immediate hemostatic control. It is typically administered orally or intramuscularly, and its delayed action makes it unsuitable for acute, severe bleeding with hemodynamic instability.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral combination contraceptive pills stabilize the endometrium over time but have a slow onset of action. In acute hemorrhage with hemodynamic instability, rapid hemostasis is needed, which oral medications cannot provide due to delayed systemic effects.

D) INCORRECT:

Hysteroscopy may be performed in the evaluation of abnormal uterine bleeding if prior imaging (e.g., pelvic ultrasound) is inconclusive or further assessment is needed. Surgical management of acute heavy vaginal bleeding (e.g., hysteroscopy for polypectomy, myomectomy, or dilation and curettage) is reserved for cases where initial pharmacotherapy fails or is contraindicated.
